cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who plays max voice in a goofy movie
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: In "A Goofy Movie," the character Max Goof is the teenage son of Goofy. The voice of Max is provided by an actor who is known for his work in animation and voice acting. To find the answer, I recall that the movie was released in 1995 and that the actor who voiced Max is also recognized for his roles in other animated films and television shows. 

Answer: Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max in "A Goofy Movie."

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who plays max voice in a goofy movie
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- "A Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n', 'Most of the main voice cast from "Goof Troop" reprised their roles in "A Goofy Movie", including Bill Farmer as Goofy, Jim Cummings as Pete, and Rob Paulsen as PJ. To conform to his difference in age, Max was played by Jason Marsden, who was in high school at the time, replacing Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the character\'s voice actor. Alternatively, Aaron Lohr did Max\'s singing voice. Other cast members included Kellie Martin as Roxanne, Jenna von Oÿ as Stacey, and Pauly Shore as Bobby Zimuruski. Farmer, who spent 43 days recording dialogue over the span of 2-and-a-half years, was initially asked by Jeffrey Katzenberg to give Goofy a regular speaking voice as opposed to the character\'s signature, cartoonish voice, much to the confusion of Farmer, who insisted that audiences wanted to hear the Goofy they were all familiar with. After recording lines in this manner for a week-and-a-half, according to Farmer, Michael Eisner and Roy E. Disney told Farmer to speak in Goofy\'s original voice, after which the dialogue was rerecorded as such. R&B artist Tevin Campbell provided the singing voice for Powerline, recording the songs "Stand Out" and "I2I". Campbell recorded the songs in front of a green screen while performing his own choreography. The film is dedicated to Pat Buttram, who voiced the emcee at possum park, as he died after finishing voice work for the film.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Mardsen as Max Goof\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof\n', 'WatchMojo.com placed the Nostalgia Critic at #2 on their Top 10 YouTube Movie Critics list. Jacob Davich, who portrayed Linus in the film, "The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl", highly praised the Critic\'s review of the film. Both Bill Farmer, the voice of Goofy, and Jason Marsden, the voice of Max, praised Channel Awesome after watching the Critic\'s editorial, "Is Goofy Secretly Badass?" Animation director Ralph Bakshi praised the review of "Cool World", finding it "very funny". On August 27, 2017, the Critic did a crossover with fellow Channel Awesome critic, Nash Bozard. For "Here There Be Dragons", Bozard\'s review series about fantasy films and adaptations, the Critic and Nash reviewed the short-lived Syfy series "The Dresden Files". Jim Butcher, the author who wrote the novel series on which the series was based, seemed to react positively, tweeting "AHAHAHAHAHAHAHA ICANTSTOPLAUGHINGHAHAHAHAHAH".\n', 'BULLET::::- Maximilian "Max" Goof" (voiced by Dana Hill), is the son and only child of Goofy. He is 11½ years old, and is in the same grade as his best friend P.J. at their junior high school. While he is generally active, alert and friendly, he can also be very cunning and/or coercive when pushed or tricked, sometimes even on par with Pete. He loves his dad, and is close to him, but wishes he would be a little more normal, feeling at times embarrassed by his father\'s clumsy and doting behavior. His interests in the series include skateboarding, video games, rock music, girls, and outwitting bullies.\n', 'BULLET::::- G. G. "Goofy" Goof (voiced by Bill Farmer) is the single father of Max Goof. In the pilot episode, he and his son move next door to the Petes from their trailer home in another city. Goofy\'s biggest weaknesses are his short attention span, scatterbrain, and clumsiness. He often drives his neighbor Pete up the proverbial wall. Goofy is very calm, lovable, and usually turns the other cheek when Pete insults him (or just doesn\'t realize he\'s been insulted). Though, occasionally, he does get angry and defensive toward Pete when the offense goes too far, but is very forgiving and still considers Pete to be his best friend no matter how often Pete is mean to him.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof (Cameo Role)\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max. Now college-bound, his attempts to distance himself from Goofy and winds up making things worse for him. By finally accepting Goofy as a major part of his life, he was able to find the independence he long sought. Bob Baxter and Steven Trenbirth served as the supervising animators for Max.\n', 'BULLET::::- "An Extremely Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n']

### Extracted Content:
1. **Voice Actor Information**:
   - Jason Marsden is identified as the voice actor for Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie."
   - He replaced Dana Hill, who voiced Max in the "Goof Troop" series, indicating a continuity in character but a change in voice actor due to the character's age progression.

2. **Singing Voice**:
   - Aaron Lohr provided Max's singing voice, which is a notable distinction since voice acting and singing can often be performed by different individuals in animated films.

3. **Character Background**:
   - Max Goof is described as the son of Goofy, who is characterized as a clumsy and doting father. This relationship dynamic is important for understanding Max's character development throughout the film.
   - Max is portrayed as a high school student who is trying to navigate his identity and relationship with his father, which adds depth to his character and the narrative of the movie.

4. **Other Cast Members**:
   - The passages mention other characters and their voice actors, such as Bill Farmer as Goofy and Jim Cummings as Pete. This context helps situate Max within the larger ensemble of characters in the film.

5. **Film Context**:
   - The film "A Goofy Movie" is a continuation of the "Goof Troop" series, which provides context for Max's character and the storyline. Understanding that Max is a continuation of a character from a previous series helps frame his development and the themes of the movie.

### Role of Extracted Content:
- **Character Development**: The information about Max's relationship with Goofy and his struggles with identity provides insight into the themes of adolescence and parental relationships, which are central to the film's narrative.
  
- **Voice Acting Dynamics**: The distinction between voice acting and singing highlights the complexity of animated productions, where different talents may be utilized for various aspects of a character's portrayal.

- **Continuity and Change**: The transition from Dana Hill to Jason Marsden as the voice of Max illustrates how animated characters can evolve over time, reflecting changes in their story arcs and the actors' own careers.

- **Ensemble Context**: Mentioning other characters and their voice actors situates Max within a broader narrative framework, allowing for a richer understanding of the film's dynamics and character interactions.

By synthesizing this information, we can confidently answer that Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie," while also appreciating the character's background and the film's context.

This change reflects the character's growth and transition from childhood to adolescence, which is a significant aspect of the film's narrative.

3. **Singing Voice**:
   - It's important to note that Aaron Lohr provided Max's singing voice in the film. This distinction highlights the common practice in animation where voice acting and singing are often performed by different individuals, showcasing the collaborative nature of animated productions.

6. **Themes and Character Development**:

By synthesizing this information, we can confidently conclude that Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie." This understanding not only answers the question but also enriches the context surrounding the character and the film.

Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie."

Task Description:

Engage in a dialogue where you imagine discussing these passages with a group of experts. Each expert presents different perspectives based on the foundational and advanced knowledge from the passages. By participating in this collaborative discussion, you will deepen the model's understanding through the synthesis of multiple expert perspectives.

**Panel Discussion on Max's Voice in "A Goofy Movie"**

**Expert 1: Animation Historian**
"From the passages, it's clear that Jason Marsden voiced Max Goof in 'A Goofy Movie.' This is significant because he replaced Dana Hill, who voiced Max in 'Goof Troop.' Marsden was a high school student at the time, which likely contributed to his ability to capture the character's youthful essence. This casting choice reflects the film's intent to portray Max as a relatable teenager."

**Expert 2: Voice Acting Specialist**
"I agree with the points made about Marsden's performance. However, it's worth noting that while he provided the speaking voice, Aaron Lohr was responsible for Max's singing voice. This duality in voice acting is not uncommon in animated films, but it does highlight the collaborative nature of voice work in animation. It raises questions about how audiences perceive character voices when they are not unified."

**Expert 3: Cultural Critic**
"That's an interesting point. The fact that two different actors voiced Max could affect how audiences connect with him. In a way, it mirrors the character's struggle for identity—trying to balance his father's goofy nature with his desire to be seen as cool. This duality might resonate with many young viewers who feel pressure to conform to social expectations."

**Expert 4: Film Scholar**
"Building on that, the casting of Jason Marsden also reflects a broader trend in animation during the 1990s, where studios began to prioritize youthful, relatable voices for teenage characters. This shift can be seen in other films from that era, where the voice actors were often closer in age to their characters, enhancing authenticity. Marsden's portrayal of Max captures the character's internal conflict beautifully, which is a central theme of the film."

**Expert 5: Musicologist**
"I'd like to add that the musical elements of the film, particularly the songs performed by Tevin Campbell as Powerline, also play a crucial role in shaping Max's character. The contrast between Marsden's speaking voice and Campbell's singing voice creates a layered representation of Max—one that is both relatable in dialogue and aspirational in song. This duality enhances the character's journey and his desire for acceptance."

**Synthesis of Insights**
The discussion reveals a multifaceted understanding of Max Goof's character in "A Goofy Movie." Jason Marsden's voice acting is pivotal in portraying Max's teenage struggles, while Aaron Lohr's contribution as the singing voice adds depth to the character's aspirations. The duality of voice actors reflects broader themes of identity and acceptance, resonating with the film's audience. Furthermore, the casting choices align with trends in the animation industry during the 1990s, emphasizing the importance of relatable voices for younger characters. The integration of music, particularly through Tevin Campbell's performances, enriches Max's character arc, making him both relatable and aspirational.

In conclusion, the collaborative insights from the panel highlight how the voice acting and musical elements in "A Goofy Movie" work together to create a complex and relatable character in Max Goof, ultimately enhancing the film's emotional impact and cultural relevance.

**Discussion-Enhanced Reasoning Process:**

In "A Goofy Movie," the character Max Goof is voiced by Jason Marsden, who took over the role from Dana Hill, the original voice actor from the "Goof Troop" series. This transition is significant as it reflects the character's evolution from a younger child to a relatable teenager, which Marsden, being a high school student at the time, was able to embody effectively. 

The discussion highlights several important aspects of voice acting and character representation. Firstly, the distinction between speaking and singing voices is crucial; while Marsden provided the speaking voice, Aaron Lohr was responsible for Max's singing voice. This duality raises interesting questions about audience perception and character identity, as it can create a layered representation of Max that resonates with viewers on different levels.

Moreover, the panel noted that the casting of youthful actors for teenage roles was a trend in the 1990s animation landscape, enhancing authenticity and relatability. Marsden's portrayal of Max captures the character's internal conflict between wanting to fit in and dealing with the quirks of his father, Goofy. This theme of identity struggle is particularly relevant to the target audience of the film, many of whom may relate to the pressures of adolescence.

Additionally, the musical contributions of Tevin Campbell as Powerline further enrich Max's character. The contrast between Marsden's and Campbell's voices creates a dynamic representation of Max, making him both relatable in dialogue and aspirational in song. This duality not only enhances Max's character arc but also contributes to the film's overall emotional impact.

In summary, the synthesis of these perspectives reveals a comprehensive understanding of Max Goof's character in "A Goofy Movie." The interplay between voice acting, character development, and musical elements creates a multifaceted portrayal that resonates with audiences, highlighting themes of identity, acceptance, and the challenges of growing up.

**Answer:**
Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie," while Aaron Lohr provides his singing voice. This duality in voice representation enhances Max's character, reflecting his struggles with identity and acceptance during adolescence.

2. **Voice Actors**:

3. **Film Context**:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
To answer the question of who plays Max's voice in "A Goofy Movie," we start by identifying the character and the context of the film. Max Goof is the teenage son of Goofy, and the film was released in 1995. 

1. **Character Context**: Max is portrayed as a high school student navigating the challenges of adolescence, including his relationship with his father, Goofy. This context is essential as it informs the character's motivations and the dynamics of his interactions.

2. **Voice Actor Identification**: The voice of Max Goof is provided by Jason Marsden. He took over the role from Dana Hill, who voiced Max in the earlier series "Goof Troop." This transition indicates an evolution in the character's portrayal, reflecting his growth from a child to a teenager.

3. **Singing Voice**: It is also important to note that Aaron Lohr provided Max's singing voice in the film. This distinction highlights how different aspects of a character can be represented through various voice actors, which can affect audience perception and engagement with the character.

4. **Thematic Elements**: The film explores themes of acceptance and independence, particularly in the context of Max's relationship with Goofy. Understanding these themes can enhance the model's ability to infer character motivations and the implications of their actions within the narrative.

5. **Adaptation Across Media**: Recognizing that Max's character evolved from "Goof Troop" to "A Goofy Movie" allows for a deeper understanding of character continuity and development across different formats. This knowledge can inform reasoning about how characters adapt to new narratives and contexts.

By synthesizing this information, we can conclude that Jason Marsden is the voice actor for Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie," and this role reflects a significant aspect of the character's development and the film's themes.

### Answer:
Jason Marsden plays the voice of Max in "A Goofy Movie."

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who plays max voice in a goofy movie
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['BULLET::::- "A Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n', 'Most of the main voice cast from "Goof Troop" reprised their roles in "A Goofy Movie", including Bill Farmer as Goofy, Jim Cummings as Pete, and Rob Paulsen as PJ. To conform to his difference in age, Max was played by Jason Marsden, who was in high school at the time, replacing Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the character\'s voice actor. Alternatively, Aaron Lohr did Max\'s singing voice. Other cast members included Kellie Martin as Roxanne, Jenna von Oÿ as Stacey, and Pauly Shore as Bobby Zimuruski. Farmer, who spent 43 days recording dialogue over the span of 2-and-a-half years, was initially asked by Jeffrey Katzenberg to give Goofy a regular speaking voice as opposed to the character\'s signature, cartoonish voice, much to the confusion of Farmer, who insisted that audiences wanted to hear the Goofy they were all familiar with. After recording lines in this manner for a week-and-a-half, according to Farmer, Michael Eisner and Roy E. Disney told Farmer to speak in Goofy\'s original voice, after which the dialogue was rerecorded as such. R&B artist Tevin Campbell provided the singing voice for Powerline, recording the songs "Stand Out" and "I2I". Campbell recorded the songs in front of a green screen while performing his own choreography. The film is dedicated to Pat Buttram, who voiced the emcee at possum park, as he died after finishing voice work for the film.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Mardsen as Max Goof\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof\n', 'WatchMojo.com placed the Nostalgia Critic at #2 on their Top 10 YouTube Movie Critics list. Jacob Davich, who portrayed Linus in the film, "The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl", highly praised the Critic\'s review of the film. Both Bill Farmer, the voice of Goofy, and Jason Marsden, the voice of Max, praised Channel Awesome after watching the Critic\'s editorial, "Is Goofy Secretly Badass?" Animation director Ralph Bakshi praised the review of "Cool World", finding it "very funny". On August 27, 2017, the Critic did a crossover with fellow Channel Awesome critic, Nash Bozard. For "Here There Be Dragons", Bozard\'s review series about fantasy films and adaptations, the Critic and Nash reviewed the short-lived Syfy series "The Dresden Files". Jim Butcher, the author who wrote the novel series on which the series was based, seemed to react positively, tweeting "AHAHAHAHAHAHAHA ICANTSTOPLAUGHINGHAHAHAHAHAH".\n', 'BULLET::::- Maximilian "Max" Goof" (voiced by Dana Hill), is the son and only child of Goofy. He is 11½ years old, and is in the same grade as his best friend P.J. at their junior high school. While he is generally active, alert and friendly, he can also be very cunning and/or coercive when pushed or tricked, sometimes even on par with Pete. He loves his dad, and is close to him, but wishes he would be a little more normal, feeling at times embarrassed by his father\'s clumsy and doting behavior. His interests in the series include skateboarding, video games, rock music, girls, and outwitting bullies.\n', 'BULLET::::- G. G. "Goofy" Goof (voiced by Bill Farmer) is the single father of Max Goof. In the pilot episode, he and his son move next door to the Petes from their trailer home in another city. Goofy\'s biggest weaknesses are his short attention span, scatterbrain, and clumsiness. He often drives his neighbor Pete up the proverbial wall. Goofy is very calm, lovable, and usually turns the other cheek when Pete insults him (or just doesn\'t realize he\'s been insulted). Though, occasionally, he does get angry and defensive toward Pete when the offense goes too far, but is very forgiving and still considers Pete to be his best friend no matter how often Pete is mean to him.\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof (Cameo Role)\n', 'BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max. Now college-bound, his attempts to distance himself from Goofy and winds up making things worse for him. By finally accepting Goofy as a major part of his life, he was able to find the independence he long sought. Bob Baxter and Steven Trenbirth served as the supervising animators for Max.\n', 'BULLET::::- "An Extremely Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)\n']

- Jason Marsden is the voice of Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie".
- Aaron Lohr provided the singing voice for Max.
- Jason Marsden replaced Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the voice of Max.

This information helps clarify the roles of different voice actors and their contributions to the character of Max Goof, addressing potential gaps or inaccuracies in the model's existing knowledge.

In "A Goofy Movie," the character Max Goof is the teenage son of Goofy. The voice of Max is provided by an actor known for his work in animation and voice acting. The movie was released in 1995, and the actor who voiced Max is recognized for his roles in other animated films and television shows.

1. **Voice Actor for Max Goof**: The passages confirm that **Jason Marsden** voices Max Goof in "A Goofy Movie." This is consistent across multiple sources, reinforcing the accuracy of this information.

question_info.question: who plays max voice in a goofy movie
passages:
BULLET::::- "A Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)
Most of the main voice cast from "Goof Troop" reprised their roles in "A Goofy Movie", including Bill Farmer as Goofy, Jim Cummings as Pete, and Rob Paulsen as PJ. To conform to his difference in age, Max was played by Jason Marsden, who was in high school at the time, replacing Dana Hill from "Goof Troop" as the character's voice actor. Alternatively, Aaron Lohr did Max's singing voice. Other cast members included Kellie Martin as Roxanne, Jenna von Oÿ as Stacey, and Pauly Shore as Bobby Zimuruski. Farmer, who spent 43 days recording dialogue over the span of 2-and-a-half years, was initially asked by Jeffrey Katzenberg to give Goofy a regular speaking voice as opposed to the character's signature, cartoonish voice, much to the confusion of Farmer, who insisted that audiences wanted to hear the Goofy they were all familiar with. After recording lines in this manner for a week-and-a-half, according to Farmer, Michael Eisner and Roy E. Disney told Farmer to speak in Goofy's original voice, after which the dialogue was rerecorded as such. R&B artist Tevin Campbell provided the singing voice for Powerline, recording the songs "Stand Out" and "I2I". Campbell recorded the songs in front of a green screen while performing his own choreography. The film is dedicated to Pat Buttram, who voiced the emcee at possum park, as he died after finishing voice work for the film.
BULLET::::- Jason Mardsen as Max Goof
BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof
WatchMojo.com placed the Nostalgia Critic at #2 on their Top 10 YouTube Movie Critics list. Jacob Davich, who portrayed Linus in the film, "The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl", highly praised the Critic's review of the film. Both Bill Farmer, the voice of Goofy, and Jason Marsden, the voice of Max, praised Channel Awesome after watching the Critic's editorial, "Is Goofy Secretly Badass?" Animation director Ralph Bakshi praised the review of "Cool World", finding it "very funny". On August 27, 2017, the Critic did a crossover with fellow Channel Awesome critic, Nash Bozard. For "Here There Be Dragons", Bozard's review series about fantasy films and adaptations, the Critic and Nash reviewed the short-lived Syfy series "The Dresden Files". Jim Butcher, the author who wrote the novel series on which the series was based, seemed to react positively, tweeting "AHAHAHAHAHAHAHA ICANTSTOPLAUGHINGHAHAHAHAHAH".
BULLET::::- Maximilian "Max" Goof" (voiced by Dana Hill), is the son and only child of Goofy. He is 11½ years old, and is in the same grade as his best friend P.J. at their junior high school. While he is generally active, alert and friendly, he can also be very cunning and/or coercive when pushed or tricked, sometimes even on par with Pete. He loves his dad, and is close to him, but wishes he would be a little more normal, feeling at times embarrassed by his father's clumsy and doting behavior. His interests in the series include skateboarding, video games, rock music, girls, and outwitting bullies.
BULLET::::- G. G. "Goofy" Goof (voiced by Bill Farmer) is the single father of Max Goof. In the pilot episode, he and his son move next door to the Petes from their trailer home in another city. Goofy's biggest weaknesses are his short attention span, scatterbrain, and clumsiness. He often drives his neighbor Pete up the proverbial wall. Goofy is very calm, lovable, and usually turns the other cheek when Pete insults him (or just doesn't realize he's been insulted). Though, occasionally, he does get angry and defensive toward Pete when the offense goes too far, but is very forgiving and still considers Pete to be his best friend no matter how often Pete is mean to him.
BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max Goof (Cameo Role)
BULLET::::- Jason Marsden as Max. Now college-bound, his attempts to distance himself from Goofy and winds up making things worse for him. By finally accepting Goofy as a major part of his life, he was able to find the independence he long sought. Bob Baxter and Steven Trenbirth served as the supervising animators for Max.
BULLET::::- "An Extremely Goofy Movie", Max Goof (Jason Marsden)
